comment: Vanilla, cherry, berries and wood. Slightly bitter on the backend of the tongue.
Just not into finished bourbons I think.

6/24/17 Total Wine, Kennesaw, GA
$84.79  = 79.99+4.80
Pritchard Hill Cab Cask Finish
Batch 1, Bottle 09503

$79

Sweet notes of dark berries, chocolate and a whole lotta cab/Port on the nose. Palate reminds me of the new basil Hayden dark rye but a little tamer. Reminds me of drinking a nice red wine while eating those raspberry dark chocolates they give ya at Arrington Vineyards but with a hotter finish of course. I really enjoyed this and think it’s definitely worth the buy but I’m biased a little because I also enjoy a nice glass of cab/port as well. It’s definitely a unique bourbon that I think you’ll either love or hate.

6/6/18
Nose: Cabernet is prominent, gentle vanilla sweetness, 
Palate: Plump red fruit, almost tropical, sweet vermouth as well
Notes: Jeff Reserve base; 14-15 months in cab casks

Bday gift from Alex
Interesting... almost like a port finish with
More heat,
TWCP store pick. Different (and better) than the standard bottle I've had. This is earthy, almost creamy. Some dirt notes, I mean that in a good way. Some slight berry hints as well. 10/27/17
Strong up front. Finish of charcoal wood and dark fruit notes. Incredibly smooth for abv. Nice to sip on. Delicious!
sample/will try again but this seems like a lot of fun!

Nice barrel finished Bourbon. Smooth and sweet with a definite pronounced dry oak finish. Upon entry it classic Bourbon. Vanilla, brown sugar and caramel. Some spice on the mid pallette with a little long wine oak and vanilla finish. Finish goes on for a long time but is rather drying like a nice Cab.
My main gripe and why I didn't score this bourbon is the price. At $80 it's simply not worth the $40 premium on the standard release. When you consider an extra $9 gets you the vastly superior Midwinter Dram, it puts this one into perspective.
Can taste a lot of wine on this one. Nice lively sip.
Decent nose and taste. Finish is blah.

Nose: Sweet and Fruity. Can smell the wine influence. 
Taste: Wine, Boring finish but when I added water to it it opened up and I actually started to enjoy it
Getting a lot of wine on the nose & palate. A little chocolate on the after taste. Medium finish.

when i first sipped it it had a lot of burn. i let it sit and  breathe and it mellowed out. the longer it sits the smoother it gets.

great flavor
It has more spice but the flavor doesn’t seem to hold up to the others in the same line
Dried cherries and slight fig on the nose. Dark red tint for color, and has more wine characteristics for taste

Big good smelling nose with lots of bright jammy fruits and citrus notes. The body and finish is a little disappointing being a speciality cask finish. The groth cask finish variation to me is much more well balanced and flavorful than this Pritchard cab finish.

N: honey, stone fruit, sourness

P: oakey, hints of grapey, sour, lemon zest

F: long, peppery but not hot, hints of oak

weird but fun
Nose is very sweet, initial taste of fruits and ending with an almond tinge, finish is a bit boozy with an ending of clear Cabernet that fills the mouth.
Good consistent drinking bottle, smooth and just a little sweet, little expensive for what it is though

Ice from Anthony Davis in COB (Jon acquires and shared). Not much on the nose, very sweet initial taste with an awkward finish (turned out to be the wine barrel finish). Would drink again and consider getting a bottle. 
Gave this a 6.5/10, Jon gave it 7.5

Pretty standard bourbon nose. The wine really comes through on the palate. Long smooth finish. Quite delicious. Better than the Groth Cask Reserve version.

Happy 4th!
Good, but not worth the premium.
Thin mouthfeel, sweet honey, butterscotch, baking spice, allspice

This is an interesting bourbon. I like the wine influence but it’s a little unbalanced - the flavors are good but the palate transitions are disjointed. The experience doesn’t match up with the price tag.

A big blast of cabernet wine, oak, tannic notes and balsamic in the nose.

The flavors in there are complex, that wine finish is present. Chewy mouthfeel gives way to cherries, baking spice, oak tannins, and black olives. Yes black olives, was hard for me to place but in sip 3 I got it.

Finish is nice. Mouth coating and sweet for being a wine finish. This begs you to go back in with its complexity and finish.
Light smokey taste, sweet fruit smell. Slightly dry finish, Cabernet essense subtle but present.
Dryness from the cabernet really comes through with grape skins on the finish?
Reminds me a lot of barrel bourbon dovetail which I absolutely love
Tannic. Thin. Carmel. Burn. Not much else. Drinkable.
Reddish-copper color. Wine barrel dominates. Tannic.

Really love the nose. Sweet and fruity scent. Very sweet with a strong up front burn. Better with a touch of water to open it up. Not the best thing I've ever drank but likely pretty good in a unique old fashioned.
Working to hard, aspires to be wine.
Has a nice nose and good taste but the finish is very cough syrup to me.
Smooth, the wine is there, too much smoke for my taste. I am a Jefferson fan and i prefer the regular reserve over this...
Not as good as I was hoping 4 but I quess I'm getting fussy ☺️
Very similar to Dovetail.  Really like the smooth taste, slight burn and fruity taste. Really a good overall whiskey.
Sweet with a very round mouthfeel and fresh berry & brown sugar sweetness. It is nice but not as good as the Yellowstone wine barrel finish.

Aroma: wine grapes, dried cherries, dark berries, figs, vanilla, and slight chocolate. Sweet and fruity.

Taste: Quite full/chewy. Taste the cabernet/grapes. Pretty much all the notes in the aroma are present in the taste, although I can taste some brown sugar, butterscotch, allspice, and honey too.

Finish: Very smooth, tiny burn in the back of throat. Can really taste the cabernet/grapes.

This whiskey is okay, but it's definitely not worth the price. Perhaps those that like sweeter stuff would like this, but I feel there's not enough oak and too much sweetness that's not balanced out. Also oddly very bitter upon finish.

Sweet aroma on the nose. The Cabernet casking is front and center. Ripe berries, grapes and honey with vanilla overtones on the nose. A rather thin texture given the richness of its scent. Cinnamon and oak on the palate. Where the smell is sweet the taste is spicy and dry. Pretty smooth, the spice is in the taste not a burn. A minty taste on the finish.
Really good stuff and the finish comes through quite well. I’m not convinced it was worth the extra cost but it is delicious and I don’t use cost for my ratings.
Smooth. No bite. Vanilla. Can definitely smell the cab

This is the red wine finished division of my barrel finished bourbon bracket. This was a blind taste test between Jefferson’s Pritchard Hill and Bardstown Phifer Pavitt. No spellchecking devices were harmed in the making of this review.

This was a slaughter. A truly unfair fight. Like Norte Dame v Alabama in a college football championship. Bardstown blew away Jefferson’s in every conceivable category, but unlike Norte Dame football, this wasn’t because Jefferson’s was bad. Bardstown was just truly exceptional. If it doesn’t win overall, I’ll be exceedingly surprised. Bardstown moves on against the winner of Slaughterhouse vs Hooker’s House. And yes, I am quite proud of that dictionally pleasing pairing. I’m literally flexing in my kitchen right now.

The tasting of Jefferson’s:

After trying the rum and Sauternes finished Jefferson’s reserve variations, I felt confident coming in that the red wine influence in this little guy would be an afterthought, if even detectable. The flavor profile for Jefferson’s reserve is just so damn opinionated, that it would take a lot to overpower it, right?

Wrong.

The nose is Jeffersonian to be sure. I get grape jelly, red pit fruits, and gummy bears. There is a noticeable difference to this nose however. I’d say someone took the dials on those scents and recalibrated. Synthetic sweetness via gummy bear was toned down, and natural sweetness via cherries and grapes turned up. I very much prefer this nose to that of Jefferson’s Reserve.

Body is a bit of a letdown. I was hoping to get a noticeable shift here too, but I couldn’t detect it. If you like Jefferson’s Reserve, you’ll like this body. Overall impression is grape jelly and gummy bears.

The finish did not disappoint! The overtly sweet body is completely removed on the first exhale. The dryness from the red wine influence is very noticeable, and I genuinely love it. Unmistakeable Cabernet flavor as well. Delicious.

This is my favorite Jefferson’s product to date. Any complaints I have about Jefferson’s Reserve’s flavor profile is toned down, replaced with an influence from red wine which I find genuinely enjoyable. I may not have any Jefferson’s on my shelf in the distant future, but if I do, I’d bet a pinky toe that it’d be this one.
Berries in the taste, wood and dried fruit after notes

Sweet on the nose. Spice on the palate. Very mild heat, but lingers. Cab cask is front and center, tries to steal the show. Very smooth, as expected with lower proof. Great nightcap to a steak and cab dinner.

There’s a few general rules or tenets in today’s life that we should live by: 
1) wear a face mask when stepping out where there’s public 
2) keep your 6 ft distance from others.  The risk isn’t worth the possible pain
3) don’t listen to folks , who couldn’t even pass basic high school biology, act as if they know what’s best when it comes to CV19
4) do NOT follow people jogging, and shoot them.  Regardless of race and creed!! 
And 5) do try a bourbon finished in good quality wine casks.  It’s so worth the experience 

This one is sent by my buddy @LeeEvolved.  ( side note: Lee—-i hope you’re taking it easy at home and recovering from that CV19 hell).  

This is a blend of 3 sourced bourbons, finished in Pritchard Hill Cabernet Sauvignon.  It’s 15yr old stock, finished in the wine barrel. 15 yr + now explains the price tag.  I wasn’t impressed with this as I was with the earlier Groth reserve.  This has tannic flavors up front, and seems like the wine is fighting with the bourbon.  But once you get past those tannins, you get the classic berries and oak soaked fruit flavors.  

Is it worth the $100-120?  Honestly...I’d rather get the Groth over this.  But I’m guessing the Groth as long since been sold out.  Either way, one thing for sure: you have to put red wine finished bourbon on your try list, preferably ones finished in high quality wine like the ones made by Groth or Pffifer Pfavit ( Bardstown ).  
Thanks for the pour Lee—I hope you’re feeling better !
Sweet finish and smooth going down. Can definitely feel it in your chest going down, but great flavor.
Nice mild after taste of cherry and citrus from the wine
Fantastic bourbon; great taste, enough rye to add sweetness without being too sweet or adding too many floral bites to the otherwise great bourbon notes.
